cardBackContents.title: Journeys Through the Camp
cardBackContents.p: The path we choose to walk.

cardBackContents.title: Whispers of the Soul
cardBackContents.p: Why this work lives in me.

detailPageContent.title: Like the Sage Who Retold the Story Differently
detailPageContent.paragraph: Like Rabbi Eliezer, who retold the tale of the Oven of Achnai (Bava Metzia 59b), not to win the argument but to reveal the deeper truth beneath the surface, we too retell the stories that define family and society. Through storytelling and visual arts, we enter the space between the letters — where values are questioned, roles are reimagined, and dignity is rediscovered.

detailPageContent.title: Like Serach bat Asher Remembering the Tune
detailPageContent.paragraph: We envision a world where, like Serach bat Asher who remembered the ancient songs of Joseph (Midrash Yalkut Shimoni, Genesis 146), forgotten truths and hidden hopes resurface in harmony. Through retelling stories from the collective memory we seek to embrace the plurality of roles and affirms every voice of the human story.

detailPageContent.title: Building Like Bezalel, Layer by Layer
detailPageContent.paragraph: As Bezalel built the Mishkan with layered purpose (Exodus 35–36), so too we build with intention.

rows: Goal 1: Gather the Materials Like the Builders of the Mishkan

As the Israelites brought their gold, thread, and mirrors to the sanctuary (Exodus 35:22), we begin by gathering the resources—funding, equipment, and inspiration—to craft spaces of meaning. These first offerings will anchor our creative presence.
Goal 2: Encircle the Camp with Voices

Like the tribes encamped around the Tabernacle, each in their place but moving as one (Numbers 2), we will build an artist community — a circle of presence — where each voice contributes to a shared center. A residency is our first tent.
Goal 3: Draw the Blueprint Like Noah

As Noah was instructed to build the ark with specific measures for the sake of life (Genesis 6), so shall we draft the plan for our future home. Not for survival, but for gathering — where creation, reflection, and resistance can dwell under one roof.

Like those who planted fig trees for future generations to enjoy (Sanhedrin 91b), we seek sustainability: earned income, recurring support, and lasting roots — so our work may nourish others long after it’s planted.

detailPageContent.title: Paths Through the Wilderness
detailPageContent.paragraph: Our strategies are like the encampments of Israel (Numbers 33) — distinct movements guided by vision, grounded in place, each step carrying sacred purpose.

rows: Like King Solomon composing thousands of parables (1 Kings 5:12), we create layered stories — flagship works that hold echoes for many kinds of ears.
As the Talmud says, 'These and those are the words of the living God' (Eruvin 13b), we make space for multiplicity, for voices often left outside the tent.
Like Rabbi Meir who wrote his own scrolls from the margins (Sanhedrin 100b), we allow for new forms, bold, fragmented, unorthodox — because truth rarely stays inside straight lines.
As a sage teaches his student not just with words but by how he walks, eats, and listens (Avot 1:1), we offer transmission of skills, resilience, and quiet courage.
Like the havruta pair sharpening each other as iron sharpens iron (Ta’anit 7a), we cultivate bonds between artists — a fellowship of insight and support.
Like the Temple built with measurements from above (Exodus 25:9), we listen for the shape of what’s needed, and build with intention, humility, and inclusion.
As Hillel stood on the rooftop to hear Torah through the skylight (Yoma 35b), we make our offerings accessible — shared in plazas, festivals, gatherings where anyone may lean in.
As children learn to shape the world by asking four questions (Pesachim 116a), we embed our work in schools — to teach inquiry, not conformity.
Like letters written in the sky (Genesis Rabbah 1:1), our digital storytelling travels far — inviting new voices to join a tradition still being written.
As the elders sat at the gates to establish justice (Deuteronomy 21:19), we seek structure — not for power, but for trust.
Like Moshe gathering seventy elders (Numbers 11:16), we call on wisdom, diversity, and shared burden.
As Joseph stored grain during abundance for times of need (Genesis 41), we steward our resources with foresight and faith.
Like a seal upon your heart and arm (Song of Songs 8:6), we shape a voice that both marks us and invites others to draw near.
As the Menorah had cups for collecting oil (Exodus 25:31–40), we build systems to catch the light — to reflect, adjust, and shine more wisely.

detailPageContent.title: As the Sanhedrin Sat in a Circle
detailPageContent.paragraph: We choose the structure of a non-profit not to preserve power, but to distribute responsibility — like the Sanhedrin seated in a semi-circle (Sanhedrin 4:3), so all voices could be heard.
listItems: Like the Ark that carried both the broken and whole tablets (Berakhot 8b), our structure honors both vision and reality.
As Moshe appointed trusted leaders to judge the people (Exodus 18:21), we aim for clarity and accountability in every decision.
Like donations brought willingly for the Mishkan, we recognize each gift not as obligation, but as holy participation (Exodus 35:21).
As the menorah was made of one piece of gold, unity does not mean uniformity — we are many parts, one purpose (Exodus 25:31).
Like the gleaning laws of the field, our structure ensures nothing is wasted and all may partake (Leviticus 23:22).
As the Temple stood at the center of the city, we aspire to be a shared center — not just of art, but of justice and imagination.

detailPageContent.title: The Whisper Behind the Curtain
detailPageContent.paragraph:
I do not know when the seed was planted — perhaps by chance, accident, or imagination. Like the wind that carried the scroll of Jeremiah across the rooftops (Jeremiah 36:23), something you said, or didn’t say, moved through me. You grew in me quietly, like the bush that burned but was not consumed (Exodus 3:2), steady and unignorable.

There is something about you that reminds my soul of dreams — not unlike Joseph’s, which were once dismissed and later returned to save nations (Genesis 37:5, 41:39). You echo the values I live by: to question, to hold, to restore. And just as Serach bat Asher remembered the song that proved Joseph was still alive (Yalkut Shimoni, Genesis 146), something in you sings what I thought was lost — and I want to keep living by that tune.

Since then, when I encounter your presence — in words, gestures, even in silence — I begin to notice what is unspoken. Like Hannah who moved her lips but made no sound (1 Samuel 1:13), your content carries echoes: fatigue, joy, longing, defiance. And I hear them.

To summarize? I do not know the reason — at least not with words. Like Eliyahu, I searched in wind, quake, and fire, but only the still small voice remained (1 Kings 19:12). That voice said: “It is the right thing to do.” And I listened.

detailPageContent.title: Three Threads, One Flame
detailPageContent.paragraph:
It began with three episodes: The wrong Miriam, Makkot 21, and The Song of Serach.

Two felt like the face of Rachel weeping for her children (Jeremiah 31:15), weariness worn with grace. One was like Esther on the second day — whimsical and brave.

And then, on a run, like a fire between two letters — the fire that is mem in the word for truth, אמת — it came: “We’re missing a Sansa Foundation.” That was the beginning.
